elements.content: The serious threat of antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections has brought an urgent need for the development of new antibacterial nanomaterials. We encapsulate glutathione (GSH)-protected gold nanoclusters (AuNCs) in zeolitic imidazolate frameworks-8 (ZIF-8) and present their potential in antibacterial capabilities. Under white light irradiation, AuNCs-embedded ZIF-8 nanocomposites show assembly-enhanced emission and reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation. AuNCs@ZIF-8 exhibit almost complete inactivation of bacterial growth within 60 min of light irradiation. Scanning electron microscopic results show that AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites are captured by bacterial cells, and the leakage of alkaline phosphatase and nucleotides from bacteria demonstrate that the photoinduced ROS can easily destroy the bacterial surface and totally kill the bacteria. Herein, our antibacterial nanocomposites have photoenhanced bactericidal capability and show promising applications for sterilization.

elements.content: In recent years, bacterial infections have emerged as a serious threat to human health and brought a major global economic loss. Especially with the emergence of the new coronavirus, it has become a priority to fight off viral and bacterial harm. Over the past decade, antibiotics were regarded as the most effective antibacterial medicine, selectively inhibiting or killing bacteria by preventing DNA replication or repair and protein synthesis. However, the widespread use of antibiotics in general medicine also has an important impact on the emergence of drug-resistant strains in patients. Among many common pathogenic strains, an antibiotic-resistant gene has already been disseminated. Consequently, the preparation of a new antibacterial material with high efficiency and safety as an alternative class of antibiotics has become a hot topic. The applications of antibacterial materials have attracted wide attention because of the significance in many fields, for instance, medicine treatment, food packaging, hygiene, water treatment, and biological medicine. With the development of nanotechnologies, researchers in relevant fields are making efforts to discover new antibacterial nanocomposites, including cationic polymers, antibacterial peptides, noble metals, photothermal agents, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)-generated agents.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, bacterial infections have emerged as a serious threat to human health and brought a major global economic loss. Especially with the emergence of the new coronavirus, it has become a priority to fight off viral and bacterial harm. Over the past decade, antibiotics were regarded as the most effective antibacterial medicine, selectively inhibiting or killing bacteria by preventing DNA replication or repair and protein synthesis. However, the widespread use of antibiotics in general medicine also has an important impact on the emergence of drug-resistant strains in patients. Among many common pathogenic strains, an antibiotic-resistant gene has already been disseminated. Consequently, the preparation of a new antibacterial material with high efficiency and safety as an alternative class of antibiotics has become a hot topic. The applications of antibacterial materials have attracted wide attention because of the significance in many fields, for instance, medicine treatment, food packaging, hygiene, water treatment, and biological medicine. With the development of nanotechnologies, researchers in relevant fields are making efforts to discover new antibacterial nanocomposites, including cationic polymers, antibacterial peptides, noble metals, photothermal agents, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)-generated agents.

elements.content: It is worth nothing that ROS-generated nanomaterial agents can be regarded as potential antibacterial agents because of the rapid oxidation of various biomacromolecules in cells. Although a low level of ROS has a significant effect on supporting the cellular life cycle, excessive ROS could generate oxidative stress, giving rise to oxidative damage to the cellular constituents (e.g., nucleotides). Through this property, ROS acts as strong oxidants to destroy targeted harmful bacteria and contributes to sterilization. Recently, the release of ROS from antibacterial materials has been realized in photocatalytic disinfection and antibacterial photodynamic therapy.
elements.clean_text: It is worth nothing that ROS-generated nanomaterial agents can be regarded as potential antibacterial agents because of the rapid oxidation of various biomacromolecules in cells. Although a low level of ROS has a significant effect on supporting the cellular life cycle, excessive ROS could generate oxidative stress, giving rise to oxidative damage to the cellular constituents (e.g., nucleotides). Through this property, ROS acts as strong oxidants to destroy targeted harmful bacteria and contributes to sterilization. Recently, the release of ROS from antibacterial materials has been realized in photocatalytic disinfection and antibacterial photodynamic therapy.

elements.content: Gold nanoclusters (AuNCs) are defined as nanostructures with <2 nm in diameter consisting of several to a hundred gold atoms. Because of their strong quantum size confinement and discrete energy levels, AuNCs exhibit strong luminescence and good biocompatibility, resulting in widespread use in bioimaging and biosensing. Meanwhile, AuNCs also display antibacterial capability after being metabolized by bacterial cells. More importantly, AuNCs can act as inorganic photosensitizers because of their long triplet-state lifetime. ROS can be generated by the energy transfer from AuNCs to molecular oxygen with light irradiation, which is especially effective for photodynamic therapy. Nevertheless, optical and chemical properties of AuNCs are highly sensitive to their capping ligands and surrounding circumstances. Consequently, it is necessary to develop AuNCs-based nanocomposites to achieve high fluorescence intensity and meanwhile improve their ROS generation. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as the name implies, are crystalline porous solids composed of a three-dimensional structure of inorganic metal ions and organic linkers. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks-8 (ZIF-8) are a kind of characteristic porous MOFs consisting of transition-metal Zn and imidazolate linkers. By virtue of their large capacity and high porosity, ZIF-8 are wildly applied as carriers of nanoenzymes, antibacterial agents and fluorescent probes in biomedical areas; hence, they can fabricate favorable composite materials. When AuNCs were entrapped in ZIF-8, quantum yields and fluorescence lifetimes of AuNCs were greatly improved because of the aggregation-induced emission. However, there is no report on antibacterial application of AuNCs-incorporated ZIF-8 nanocomposites because of their photoinduced ROS generation. Therefore, it is important to study ROS release of AuNCs as photosensitizers and explore their ROS-induced photodynamic effect when AuNCs are encapsulated in ZIF-8, evidently contributing to photoinduced antibacterial applications.

elements.content: In this work, herein, we design a novel antibacterial agent by incorporating AuNCs into a ZIF-8 matrix (AuNCs@ZIF-8) through simple coordination-assisted self-assembly for safe, rapid, and effective bacterial disinfection. AuNCs@ZIF-8 can be readily irradiated by a white light source to produce ROS, where the ROS production amount is highly improved when many AuNCs are incorporated into ZIF-8. After AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites are captured by bacterial cells, photoinduced ROS can easily attach to the bacterial surface and totally destroy the bacteria (). AuNCs@ZIF-8 are regarded as ROS storage that have an extinctive impact on bactericidal activities.

elements.content: AuNCs were incorporated in a ZIF-8 matrix to form AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites through simple coordination-assisted self-assembly. Zn2+ ions of ZIF-8 have a coordinative interaction with the carboxyl group in glutathione (GSH)-protected AuNCs. The morphologies of AuNCs@ZIF-8 and AuNCs were first characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (a and Figure S1). The prepared AuNCs@ZIF-8 have monodispersibility and a uniform size of 75 ± 9 nm. In comparison to ZIF-8 (a, insert), no obvious difference was observed in the shape and size of AuNCs@ZIF-8, indicating that AuNCs were confined in the framework of ZIF-8 without affecting its morphology. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) results further demonstrated that the incorporation of AuNCs into a ZIF-8 matrix did not change the ZIF-8 skeleton, as the XRD pattern of AuNCs@ZIF-8 was almost identical to that of pure ZIF-8 (b). TEM and XRD results demonstrated that the incorporation of AuNCs cannot change the ZIF-8 morphology and skeleton.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

Synthesis of AuNCs@ZIF-8 Nanocomposites

AuNCs were incorporated in a ZIF-8 matrix to form AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites through simple coordination-assisted self-assembly. Zn2+ ions of ZIF-8 have a coordinative interaction with the carboxyl group in glutathione (GSH)-protected AuNCs. The morphologies of AuNCs@ZIF-8 and AuNCs were first characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (a and Figure S1). The prepared AuNCs@ZIF-8 have monodispersibility and a uniform size of 75 ± 9 nm. In comparison to ZIF-8 (a, insert), no obvious difference was observed in the shape and size of AuNCs@ZIF-8, indicating that AuNCs were confined in the framework of ZIF-8 without affecting its morphology. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) results further demonstrated that the incorporation of AuNCs into a ZIF-8 matrix did not change the ZIF-8 skeleton, as the XRD pattern of AuNCs@ZIF-8 was almost identical to that of pure ZIF-8 (b). TEM and XRD results demonstrated that the incorporation of AuNCs cannot change the ZIF-8 morphology and skeleton.

Inset: The elemental composition and content of AuNCs@ZIF-8; (d) photoluminescence (PL) spectra of AuNCs@ZIF-8, AuNCs and ZIF-8; (e) XPS survey spectrum of AuNCs@ZIF-8 and (f) Au 4f and Zn 3p in AuNCs@ZIF-8.

elements.content: Furthermore, energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), photoluminescence, and X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) analyses confirmed that the AuNCs were incorporated into the ZIF-8 framework successfully. EDS results showed that the elements Zn, C, N, and O were the main components of the system and the elements Au and S verified the incorporation of AuNCs in ZIF-8 (c and Figure S2). Moreover, compared to pure AuNCs, AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites have obvious fluorescence enhancement. After incorporation, the fluorescence intensity of the AuNCs in the nanocomposites was ∼10 times as high as that of the free ones (d). The fluorescence intensity of the AuNCs was enhanced in the matrix confinement because of the aggregation-induced emission of AuNCs, reducing the collisions with solvents and restraining the vibration and rotation of excited AuNCs. Meanwhile, the fluorescence of AuNCs slightly turned from orange red to yellow, which was in accord with the slight negative shift of the fluorescence spectra (d insert). Additionally, XPS analysis provided information on the elemental composition and chemical states of elements in the composite materials. The XPS fully scanned spectrum showed the presence of Zn 2p, O 1s, N 1s, C 1s, S 2p, and Au 4f signals in the range of 0–1200 eV (e). Compared to the previous report of AuNCs (84.1 eV), the XPS spectrum of Au 4f7/2 (83.6 eV) in AuNCs@ZIF-8 exhibited a slight negative shift, which might be due to the electron transfer between AuNCs and ZIF-8 (f). The XPS results further confirmed the existence of AuNCs in ZIF-8 nanocomposites.

elements.content: 2,7-Dichlorodihydrofluorescein (DCFH) was used as a probe to detect ROS production, where nonfluorescence DCFH is rapidly oxidized by ROS to become dichlorofluorescein (DCF), which emitted fluorescence at 525 nm of wavelength. The fluorescence intensity of DCFH-containing solution increased upon irradiation with a Xe lamp for 10 min, suggesting the increase of ROS generation in the solution (). When without irradiation (in dark), there is almost no fluorescence signal for DCFH containing phosphate buffered saline (PBS), AuNCs, and ZIF-8 during the 10 min detection (the three lines almost overlapped), and AuNCs@ZIF-8 have a little bit of fluorescence because of the fluorescent emission of incorporated AuNCs. After light illumination, both free ZIF-8 and free AuNCs showed an increase of fluorescence intensity that was attributed to their ROS generation. The formation of ROS from ZIF-8 might be from the activation of oxygen molecules by photoinduced Zn+ intermediate catalytic centers within porous ZIF-8 through electron transfer. Additionally, ROS generation of AuNCs could be facilitated by photoinduced energy transfer to oxygen molecules from triplet excited states of AuNCs. In comparison to free AuNCs and ZIF-8, AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites showed the fastest increase of fluorescence intensity, even higher than the summation of free AuNCs and free ZIF-8. It showed that incorporation of AuNCs in the ZIF-8 mixture efficiently enhanced the generation of ROS. The results were in agreement with their enhanced phosphorescence emission. In the literature, a similar phenomenon was found where AuNCs embedded in a polysaccharide/polypeptide hybrid matrix also promoted the ROS generation and phosphorescence emission. In our work, the ZIF-8 matrix took advantage of the microporous structure to provide an effective pathway for transmitting the ROS generated by AuNCs, and meanwhile ZIF-8 itself can generate ROS. Constructing the composite material with different components can play a part in the preponderance of each component to achieve the synergistic effect of higher ROS generation. It provided a commendable foundation for further study of the antibacterial effect of AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites.
elements.clean_text:
Photoinduced ROS Generation

2,7-Dichlorodihydrofluorescein (DCFH) was used as a probe to detect ROS production, where nonfluorescence DCFH is rapidly oxidized by ROS to become dichlorofluorescein (DCF), which emitted fluorescence at 525 nm of wavelength. The fluorescence intensity of DCFH-containing solution increased upon irradiation with a Xe lamp for 10 min, suggesting the increase of ROS generation in the solution (). When without irradiation (in dark), there is almost no fluorescence signal for DCFH containing phosphate buffered saline (PBS), AuNCs, and ZIF-8 during the 10 min detection (the three lines almost overlapped), and AuNCs@ZIF-8 have a little bit of fluorescence because of the fluorescent emission of incorporated AuNCs. After light illumination, both free ZIF-8 and free AuNCs showed an increase of fluorescence intensity that was attributed to their ROS generation. The formation of ROS from ZIF-8 might be from the activation of oxygen molecules by photoinduced Zn+ intermediate catalytic centers within porous ZIF-8 through electron transfer. Additionally, ROS generation of AuNCs could be facilitated by photoinduced energy transfer to oxygen molecules from triplet excited states of AuNCs. In comparison to free AuNCs and ZIF-8, AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites showed the fastest increase of fluorescence intensity, even higher than the summation of free AuNCs and free ZIF-8. It showed that incorporation of AuNCs in the ZIF-8 mixture efficiently enhanced the generation of ROS. The results were in agreement with their enhanced phosphorescence emission. In the literature, a similar phenomenon was found where AuNCs embedded in a polysaccharide/polypeptide hybrid matrix also promoted the ROS generation and phosphorescence emission. In our work, the ZIF-8 matrix took advantage of the microporous structure to provide an effective pathway for transmitting the ROS generated by AuNCs, and meanwhile ZIF-8 itself can generate ROS. Constructing the composite material with different components can play a part in the preponderance of each component to achieve the synergistic effect of higher ROS generation. It provided a commendable foundation for further study of the antibacterial effect of AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites.

elements.content: Photoinduced antibacterial activities of AuNCs@ZIF-8 were detected using a spread plate method. In view of their excellent ROS generation capability, AuNCs@ZIF-8 were analyzed with additional antibacterial tests and compared to AuNCs and ZIF-8. a,b showed that AuNCs@ZIF-8 almost completely inhibited the growth of Gram-negative Escherichia coli (E. coli) after 60 min of light illumination (approximately 0% cell viability), whereas AuNCs@ZIF-8 without light showed 39.4% cell viability, suggesting AuNCs@ZIF-8 could efficiently inhibit bacterial growth with the assistance of light irradiation. The results could be explained by the abundant ROS generation of AuNCs@ZIF-8 induced by light. Additionally, the partial cell death induced by AuNCs@ZIF-8 in dark might be due to the intrinsic antibacterial property of AuNCs and ZIF-8. Metal ions Zn2+ from ZIF-8 were responsible for inhibiting and killing the bacteria. Reducing the size of the nanoparticles down to the nanoclusters range could enhance antimicrobial activity. AuNCs or ZIF-8 with light irradiation showed 55.5% and 33.1% cell viability, which was slightly lower than the AuNCs and ZIF-8 without light, suggesting that the ROS generation from free AuNCs or free ZIF-8 by light was too low to induce total cell death. As shown in c,d, after 60 min of light irradiation, AuNCs@ZIF-8 also exhibited superior antibacterial activity (approximately 0% cell viability) to Gram-positive Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) compared to control samples (9.8% for AuNCs and 4.3% for ZIF-8), suggesting a certain amount of ROS was required to achieve complete sterilization. Treatment with AuNCs@ZIF-8, ZIF-8, and AuNCs without light irradiation, the cell viability was 22.1%, 32.4%, and 51.4%, respectively. The results demonstrated that AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites exhibited a distinguished photoenhanced antibacterial effect, and combining two antibacterial materials into a single system can achieve higher antibacterial activities.
elements.clean_text:
Photoinduced Disinfection Performance

Photoinduced antibacterial activities of AuNCs@ZIF-8 were detected using a spread plate method. In view of their excellent ROS generation capability, AuNCs@ZIF-8 were analyzed with additional antibacterial tests and compared to AuNCs and ZIF-8. a,b showed that AuNCs@ZIF-8 almost completely inhibited the growth of Gram-negative Escherichia coli (E. coli) after 60 min of light illumination (approximately 0% cell viability), whereas AuNCs@ZIF-8 without light showed 39.4% cell viability, suggesting AuNCs@ZIF-8 could efficiently inhibit bacterial growth with the assistance of light irradiation. The results could be explained by the abundant ROS generation of AuNCs@ZIF-8 induced by light. Additionally, the partial cell death induced by AuNCs@ZIF-8 in dark might be due to the intrinsic antibacterial property of AuNCs and ZIF-8. Metal ions Zn2+ from ZIF-8 were responsible for inhibiting and killing the bacteria. Reducing the size of the nanoparticles down to the nanoclusters range could enhance antimicrobial activity. AuNCs or ZIF-8 with light irradiation showed 55.5% and 33.1% cell viability, which was slightly lower than the AuNCs and ZIF-8 without light, suggesting that the ROS generation from free AuNCs or free ZIF-8 by light was too low to induce total cell death. As shown in c,d, after 60 min of light irradiation, AuNCs@ZIF-8 also exhibited superior antibacterial activity (approximately 0% cell viability) to Gram-positive Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) compared to control samples (9.8% for AuNCs and 4.3% for ZIF-8), suggesting a certain amount of ROS was required to achieve complete sterilization. Treatment with AuNCs@ZIF-8, ZIF-8, and AuNCs without light irradiation, the cell viability was 22.1%, 32.4%, and 51.4%, respectively. The results demonstrated that AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites exhibited a distinguished photoenhanced antibacterial effect, and combining two antibacterial materials into a single system can achieve higher antibacterial activities.

elements.content: As presented in , with the illumination time increasing from 0 to 60 min, the cell viability of bacteria treated by AuNCs@ZIF-8 was gradually decreasing, which was due to the continuous increase of ROS releasing amount. After 20 min of illumination, the bactericidal effect of AuNCs@ZIF-8 was already obvious, but there was 39.7% and 18.0% cell viability for E. coli and S. aureus respectively. When the illumination time increased to 60 min, both E. coli and S. aureus cells were totally inactivated. Moreover, the sterilizing effect of AuNCs@ZIF-8 was better at S. aureus than at E. coli. In other words, S. aureus was more sensitive to this photosensitizer. It might be because Gram-negative E. coli has an extra outer membrane barrier compared to Gram-positive S. aureus. Hence, plenty of ROS generated by AuNCs@ZIF-8 caused oxidative damage to the cellular constituents and exhibited apparent antibacterial effects.

elements.content: For further investigation of the disinfection mechanism, the morphology and cell wall integrity of bacterial cells were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM); E. coli control without treatment was rod-shaped with a complete cell wall and smooth surface (a). After treatment with AuNCs@ZIF-8 in the dark, the bacterial cells were surrounded by the nanocomposites and their cell walls were almost unchanged (b). After treatment with AuNCs@ZIF-8 under 20 min of light irradiation, the cell walls became partially wrinkled and incomplete (c). In addition, d shows that S. aureus cells without treatment were smooth and sphere-shaped; meanwhile, the cells treated with AuNCs@ZIF-8 in the dark also looked plump (e). After experiencing AuNCs@ZIF-8 and light illumination, the cells were out of shape and the cell walls were damaged and uneven (f). With light illumination, it was obviously observed that many AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites attached to the bacterial cell wall, and some of them even diffused into the cell wall and destroyed their integrity (c,f). The adsorption of nanoparticles onto the cell wall was due to the electric attraction between positively charged AuNCs@ZIF-8 (+27.4 mV) and negatively charged bacterial cells, which was significant for antibacterial agents to exert their bactericidal effect. The nanocomposites could destroy the cell wall more efficiently in virtue of the strong interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism of Disinfection

For further investigation of the disinfection mechanism, the morphology and cell wall integrity of bacterial cells were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM); E. coli control without treatment was rod-shaped with a complete cell wall and smooth surface (a). After treatment with AuNCs@ZIF-8 in the dark, the bacterial cells were surrounded by the nanocomposites and their cell walls were almost unchanged (b). After treatment with AuNCs@ZIF-8 under 20 min of light irradiation, the cell walls became partially wrinkled and incomplete (c). In addition, d shows that S. aureus cells without treatment were smooth and sphere-shaped; meanwhile, the cells treated with AuNCs@ZIF-8 in the dark also looked plump (e). After experiencing AuNCs@ZIF-8 and light illumination, the cells were out of shape and the cell walls were damaged and uneven (f). With light illumination, it was obviously observed that many AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites attached to the bacterial cell wall, and some of them even diffused into the cell wall and destroyed their integrity (c,f). The adsorption of nanoparticles onto the cell wall was due to the electric attraction between positively charged AuNCs@ZIF-8 (+27.4 mV) and negatively charged bacterial cells, which was significant for antibacterial agents to exert their bactericidal effect. The nanocomposites could destroy the cell wall more efficiently in virtue of the strong interaction.

elements.content: In summary, we designed a photoinduced ROS-generated antibacterial agent for bacterial disinfection. ZIF-8 was used as a carrier for encapsulating AuNCs because of their high porosity and good biocompatibility. AuNCs embedded in ZIF-8 showed assembly-enhanced photoinduced ROS production. After 60 min of light irradiation, AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites initiated severe oxidative stress to totally kill the bacterial cells, which attributed to their capture by bacterial cells and subsequent destruction of the bacterial cell wall. This article provides a valuable and novel strategy to develop ROS-generated antimicrobial materials with photoenhanced bactericidal capability.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we designed a photoinduced ROS-generated antibacterial agent for bacterial disinfection. ZIF-8 was used as a carrier for encapsulating AuNCs because of their high porosity and good biocompatibility. AuNCs embedded in ZIF-8 showed assembly-enhanced photoinduced ROS production. After 60 min of light irradiation, AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites initiated severe oxidative stress to totally kill the bacterial cells, which attributed to their capture by bacterial cells and subsequent destruction of the bacterial cell wall. This article provides a valuable and novel strategy to develop ROS-generated antimicrobial materials with photoenhanced bactericidal capability.

Materials

elements.content: pH values of the solutions were measured by using a Mettler Toledo FE20/EL20 Laboratory pH meter. TEM images were obtained with a JEOL JEM-1200EX electron microscope operating at 100 kV with the dispersions that were dropped onto carbon-coated copper grids and then dried in air. High-resolution transmission electron microscope images were obtained with a JEOL JEM-1200EX electron microscope operating at 100 kV. The fluorescence spectra were obtained on a Shimadzu RF-5301PC spectrofluorophotometer. The zeta potential of AuNCs@ZIF-8 was measured with a Brookhaven ZetaPlus apparatus. The UV–vis absorption spectrum was recorded on a Shimadzu UV-1800 spectrophotometer. The powder XRD patterns were recorded on a Rigaku D-Max 2550 diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) at a scanning speed of 4 min–1. XPS was performed on a Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250XI spectroscopy. EDS and electron-mapping measurements attached to an SEM were used to analyze the composition. A 300 W Xe lamp coupled with an AM 1.5 filter (400 < λ < 780 nm) was employed as a light source with an optical power density fixed at 100 mW cm –2 (1 sun) to simulate sunlight irradiation.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of AuNCs

AuNCs were synthesized in a water bath according to a previous report at 70 °C. Concisely, the aqueous solution of HAuCl4⋅4H2O (40 mM, 1 mL) was mixed with GSH (100 mM, 0.6 mL) and ultrapure water (18.4 mL). Then the solution was heated to 70 °C under stirring for 24 h and then cooled to 0 °C. The AuNCs were purified using a dialysis bag. The purified AuNCs solution was adjusted to 20 mL and stored at 4 °C for the following experiments.

elements.content: AuNCs@ZIF-8 was synthesized according to a previously reported method with a little revision. One milliliter of AuNCs was precipitated with Zn­(NO3)2 aqueous solution (80 μL, 40 mg mL–1). After removal of the supernatant, the precipitated AuNCs were speedily injected into the mixture of Zn­(NO3)2 methanol solution (2 mL, 35 mM) and 2-methylimidazole (2-Melm) methanol solution (2 mL, 160 mM) under magnetic stirring (500 rpm). After 12 h, the resulting precipitate was centrifuged, washed, and vacuum-dried at 60 °C to obtain a light yellow powder. In the following assays, the final concentration of AuNCs@ZIF-8 in the system was 500 μg mL–1 and the dosage of free AuNCs (or free ZIF-8) was the same between AuNCs@ZIF-8 and AuNCs groups (or ZIF-8 group).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of AuNCs@ZIF-8 Nanocomposites

AuNCs@ZIF-8 was synthesized according to a previously reported method with a little revision. One milliliter of AuNCs was precipitated with Zn(NO3)2 aqueous solution (80 μL, 40 mg mL-1). After removal of the supernatant, the precipitated AuNCs were speedily injected into the mixture of Zn(NO3)2 methanol solution (2 mL, 35 mM) and 2-methylimidazole (2-Melm) methanol solution (2 mL, 160 mM) under magnetic stirring (500 rpm). After 12 h, the resulting precipitate was centrifuged, washed, and vacuum-dried at 60 °C to obtain a light yellow powder. In the following assays, the final concentration of AuNCs@ZIF-8 in the system was 500 μg mL-1 and the dosage of free AuNCs (or free ZIF-8) was the same between AuNCs@ZIF-8 and AuNCs groups (or ZIF-8 group).

elements.content: The ROS can oxidize nonfluorescent DCFH to fluorescent DFC. The fluorescent compound is a specific indicator for ROS (λex = 488 nm; λem = 525 nm). DCFH ethanol solution (250 μL, 1 mM) was added to sodium hydroxide solution (1 mL, 0.01 mM) and diluted with 5 mL of PBS in the dark to hydrolyze for 30 min. Then 200 μL of the AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites, AuNCs, and ZIF-8 were injected into 1 mL of DCFH solution, respectively. After irradiation with a Xe lamp at a density of 100 mW cm–2 for 1 min intervals, their fluorescence spectra were measured with 488 nm of excitation wavelength.

Bacterial Cell Culture

 E. coli and S. aureus were selected as model bacteria. They were cultured in a LB medium at 37 °C with shaking at 250 rpm for 20 h. After centrifugation (3000 rpm, 10 min), the cultured bacteria were dispersed in PBS at a concentration of 1 × 108 CFU mL-1 for the following experiments.

elements.content: Typically, 10 μL of the bacterial solution (1 × 108 CFU mL–1) and 200 μL of the AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites, AuNCs, and ZIF-8 were respectively injected into 790 μL of the PBS. Then each solution was irradiated under a Xe lamp for a total of 60 min. As the reaction progressed, 100 μL of the mixture was taken out at 20 min intervals, which were determined by a standard plate count method to count the cell viability of bacteria.
elements.clean_text:
Antibacterial Activity of AuNCs@ZIF-8

Typically, 10 μL of the bacterial solution (1 × 108 CFU mL-1) and 200 μL of the AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites, AuNCs, and ZIF-8 were respectively injected into 790 μL of the PBS. Then each solution was irradiated under a Xe lamp for a total of 60 min. As the reaction progressed, 100 μL of the mixture was taken out at 20 min intervals, which were determined by a standard plate count method to count the cell viability of bacteria.

elements.content: The E. coli and S. aureus bacterial suspensions mixed with AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites in PBS were irradiated under a Xe lamp for 20 min. After centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 5 min and washing with PBS, the precipitate was fixed with 2.5% (v/v) glutaraldehyde for 4 h at 4 °C, dehydrated by an ascending series of ethanol washes (30%, 50%, 80%, and 100%). The prepared samples were gold-sputtered followed by SEM observation.
elements.clean_text:
SEM Analysis

The E. coli and S. aureus bacterial suspensions mixed with AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites in PBS were irradiated under a Xe lamp for 20 min. After centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 5 min and washing with PBS, the precipitate was fixed with 2.5% (v/v) glutaraldehyde for 4 h at 4 °C, dehydrated by an ascending series of ethanol washes (30%, 50%, 80%, and 100%). The prepared samples were gold-sputtered followed by SEM observation.

elements.content: The activity of AKP, an extracellular enzyme, serves as an index for the permeability of the bacterial cell wall. After illumination for 60 min, the mixture of bacteria (10 μL, 1 × 108 CFU mL–1) and 200 μL of AuNCs@ZIF-8 or PBS (control group) were centrifuged for removal of the precipitate. The supernatant was analyzed with an AKP assay kit (cat. no. a059-1; Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute) and the OD at 520 nm was measured to detect AKP activity.
elements.clean_text:
Determination of AKP Activity

The activity of AKP, an extracellular enzyme, serves as an index for the permeability of the bacterial cell wall. After illumination for 60 min, the mixture of bacteria (10 μL, 1 × 108 CFU mL-1) and 200 μL of AuNCs@ZIF-8 or PBS (control group) were centrifuged for removal of the precipitate. The supernatant was analyzed with an AKP assay kit (cat. no. a059-1; Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute) and the OD at 520 nm was measured to detect AKP activity.

elements.content: The 10 μL of bacterial suspensions (1 × 108 CFU mL–1) mixed with 200 μL of AuNCs@ZIF-8 or PBS (control group) were irradiated under a Xe lamp for 60 min. The mixture was centrifuged (12000 rpm, 10 min) and the supernatant was filtered with a filter membrane. Finally, the OD of the resulting solution was measured at 260 nm (OD 260) using a microplate reader.
elements.clean_text:
Determination of Released Nucleotides

The 10 μL of bacterial suspensions (1 × 108 CFU mL-1) mixed with 200 μL of AuNCs@ZIF-8 or PBS (control group) were irradiated under a Xe lamp for 60 min. The mixture was centrifuged (12000 rpm, 10 min) and the supernatant was filtered with a filter membrane. Finally, the OD of the resulting solution was measured at 260 nm (OD 260) using a microplate reader.

Then the solution was heated to 70 °C under stirring for 24 h and then cooled to 0 °C. The AuNCs were purified using a dialysis bag. The purified AuNCs solution was adjusted to 20 mL and stored at 4 °C for the following experiments.

Synthesis of AuNCs@ZIF-8 Nanocomposites

AuNCs@ZIF-8 was synthesized according to a previously reported method with a little revision. One milliliter of AuNCs was precipitated with Zn­(NO3)2 aqueous solution (80 μL, 40 mg mL–1). After removal of the supernatant, the precipitated AuNCs were speedily injected into the mixture of Zn­(NO3)2 methanol solution (2 mL, 35 mM) and 2-methylimidazole (2-Melm) methanol solution (2 mL, 160 mM) under magnetic stirring (500 rpm). After 12 h, the resulting precipitate was centrifuged, washed, and vacuum-dried at 60 °C to obtain a light yellow powder. In the following assays, the final concentration of AuNCs@ZIF-8 in the system was 500 μg mL–1 and the dosage of free AuNCs (or free ZIF-8) was the same between AuNCs@ZIF-8 and AuNCs groups (or ZIF-8 group).

Bacterial Cell Culture

E. coli and S. aureus were selected as model bacteria. They were cultured in a LB medium at 37 °C with shaking at 250 rpm for 20 h. After centrifugation (3000 rpm, 10 min), the cultured bacteria were dispersed in PBS at a concentration of 1 × 108 CFU mL–1 for the following experiments.

cln_elements.content:
Furthermore, energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), photoluminescence, and X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) analyses confirmed that the AuNCs were incorporated into the ZIF-8 framework successfully. EDS results showed that the elements Zn, C, N, and O were the main components of the system and the elements Au and S verified the incorporation of AuNCs in ZIF-8 (c and Figure S2). Moreover, compared to pure AuNCs, AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites have obvious fluorescence enhancement. After incorporation, the fluorescence intensity of the AuNCs in the nanocomposites was ∼10 times as high as that of the free ones (d). The fluorescence intensity of the AuNCs was enhanced in the matrix confinement because of the aggregation-induced emission of AuNCs, reducing the collisions with solvents and restraining the vibration and rotation of excited AuNCs. Meanwhile, the fluorescence of AuNCs slightly turned from orange red to yellow, which was in accord with the slight negative shift of the fluorescence spectra (d insert). Additionally, XPS analysis provided information on the elemental composition and chemical states of elements in the composite materials. The XPS fully scanned spectrum showed the presence of Zn 2p, O 1s, N 1s, C 1s, S 2p, and Au 4f signals in the range of 0–1200 eV (e). Compared to the previous report of AuNCs (84.1 eV), the XPS spectrum of Au 4f7/2 (83.6 eV) in AuNCs@ZIF-8 exhibited a slight negative shift, which might be due to the electron transfer between AuNCs and ZIF-8 (f). The XPS results further confirmed the existence of AuNCs in ZIF-8 nanocomposites.

Photoinduced Disinfection Performance

Photoinduced antibacterial activities of AuNCs@ZIF-8 were detected using a spread plate method. In view of their excellent ROS generation capability, AuNCs@ZIF-8 were analyzed with additional antibacterial tests and compared to AuNCs and ZIF-8. a,b showed that AuNCs@ZIF-8 almost completely inhibited the growth of Gram-negative Escherichia coli (E. coli) after 60 min of light illumination (approximately 0% cell viability), whereas AuNCs@ZIF-8 without light showed 39.4% cell viability, suggesting AuNCs@ZIF-8 could efficiently inhibit bacterial growth with the assistance of light irradiation. The results could be explained by the abundant ROS generation of AuNCs@ZIF-8 induced by light. Additionally, the partial cell death induced by AuNCs@ZIF-8 in dark might be due to the intrinsic antibacterial property of AuNCs and ZIF-8. Metal ions Zn2+ from ZIF-8 were responsible for inhibiting and killing the bacteria. Reducing the size of the nanoparticles down to the nanoclusters range could enhance antimicrobial activity. AuNCs or ZIF-8 with light irradiation showed 55.5% and 33.1% cell viability, which was slightly lower than the AuNCs and ZIF-8 without light, suggesting that the ROS generation from free AuNCs or free ZIF-8 by light was too low to induce total cell death. As shown in c,d, after 60 min of light irradiation, AuNCs@ZIF-8 also exhibited superior antibacterial activity (approximately 0% cell viability) to Gram-positive Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) compared to control samples (9.8% for AuNCs and 4.3% for ZIF-8), suggesting a certain amount of ROS was required to achieve complete sterilization. Treatment with AuNCs@ZIF-8, ZIF-8, and AuNCs without light irradiation, the cell viability was 22.1%, 32.4%, and 51.4%, respectively. The results demonstrated that AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites exhibited a distinguished photoenhanced antibacterial effect, and combining two antibacterial materials into a single system can achieve higher antibacterial activities.

As presented in , with the illumination time increasing from 0 to 60 min, the cell viability of bacteria treated by AuNCs@ZIF-8 was gradually decreasing, which was due to the continuous increase of ROS releasing amount. After 20 min of illumination, the bactericidal effect of AuNCs@ZIF-8 was already obvious, but there was 39.7% and 18.0% cell viability for E. coli and S. aureus respectively. When the illumination time increased to 60 min, both E. coli and S. aureus cells were totally inactivated. Moreover, the sterilizing effect of AuNCs@ZIF-8 was better at S. aureus than at E. coli. In other words, S. aureus was more sensitive to this photosensitizer. It might be because Gram-negative E. coli has an extra outer membrane barrier compared to Gram-positive S. aureus. Hence, plenty of ROS generated by AuNCs@ZIF-8 caused oxidative damage to the cellular constituents and exhibited apparent antibacterial effects.

For evaluation of the cell wall permeability and leakage of genetic materials, alkaline phosphatase (AKP) activity and leakage of nucleotides were analyzed in the bacterial cells treated with AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites and light illumination. AKP exists between the cell wall and cell membrane, which is a superior index for cell wall permeability. The optical density (OD) value at 520 nm (OD 520) can be measured to detect AKP activity. As shown in a, in contrast to the control group, treatment with AuNCs@ZIF-8 and light irradiation caused an increase by 70 and 700 times in the amount of AKP leakage in E. coli and S. aureus bacterial cells, respectively (***p < 0.001). The extracellular AKP activity was in line with the SEM images, demonstrating the cell wall has been damaged after treatment.

In other words, S. aureus was more sensitive to this photosensitizer. It might be because Gram-negative E. coli has an extra outer membrane barrier compared to Gram-positive S. aureus. Hence, plenty of ROS generated by AuNCs@ZIF-8 caused oxidative damage to the cellular constituents and exhibited apparent antibacterial effects.

For evaluation of the cell wall permeability and leakage of genetic materials, alkaline phosphatase (AKP) activity and leakage of nucleotides were analyzed in the bacterial cells treated with AuNCs@ZIF-8 nanocomposites and light illumination. AKP exists between the cell wall and cell membrane, which is a superior index for cell wall permeability. The optical density (OD) value at 520 nm (OD 520) can be measured to detect AKP activity. As shown in a, in contrast to the control group, treatment with AuNCs@ZIF-8 and light irradiation caused an increase by 70 and 700 times in the amount of AKP leakage in E. coli and S. aureus bacterial cells, respectively (***p < 0.001). The extracellular AKP activity was in line with the SEM images, demonstrating the cell wall has been damaged after treatment.
